Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Quantum Nanosystems Understood the Multiscale Way
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematical and computational methods for understanding quantum nanosystems are developed based on a methodology that takes advantage of the separation of scales between the average nearest-neighbor distance and the overall system size. The deductive methodology starts with the N-fermion wave equation and results in coarse-grained equations for nanometer-nanosecond scale excitations. The coarse-grained wave equations yield the quantum dynamics of order parameters describing nanoscale features. Several types of order parameters (e.g., scaled particle positions, overall system deformation, and spin/number density profiles) are considered. The theory is based on a hypothesis that the wave function has multiple dependencies on the N-particle configuration, directly and indirectly via a set of order parameters. The result is a rigorous algorithm for simulating the long space-time scale dynamics of quantum nanosystems. Examples of applications are quantum dots, graphene flakes and nanoribbons.

The project has impact on the theory of the quantum behavior of macromolecular assemblies, quantum dots, graphene-like structures, and other quantum nanosystems. Theory, algorithms, and software resulting from this project have impact on the computer-aided design of nanoscale quantum devices, the designing of superconducting nanostructures and other anomalous circuit elements. Collaboration with Prairie View A & M University engages underrepresented groups, both students and faculty, in the two institutions via several educational activities spanning the academic year and the summer. This EAGER project is supported by a joint award including two programs in the Chemistry Division (Theory, Models and Computational Methods and Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry) and the
Division of Mathematical Sciences (Applied Mathematics program).

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Conductors, semiconductors, superconductors and graphene are examples of materials whose properties follow from the behavior of many electrons interacting across multiple scales in space and time. These lengthscales include the average nearest-neighbor electron distance, the spacing of the ion cores constituting, e.g., the metal lattice, the size of the nano- or micro-device, or more subtle lengths such as the superconducting coherence distance or the wavelength of an electron arising from its dual particle- and wave-like nature. These multiple characteristic lengths reflect themselves in the multiple timescales on which electron motion takes place.

The conceptual and practical challenges encountered in understanding these systems stems from the fact that these multiple scales reflect themselves in the structure of the wave function Ψ that must be unraveled to understand these many electron systems and predict their properties. In this project we develop a theory that accounts for the above range of characteristic scales. We start with a general hypothesis on the dependence of Ψ on the many-electron configuration, i.e., both directly and, via a set of coarse-grained (CG) variables, indirectly. With this and the Schrödinger equation for  we derive equations for the largescale (i.e., CG) behavior of a system. These equations describe the longscale collective and single-particle behaviors of the many-electron system. All factors in these CG quantum equations are related to those in the Schrödinger equation of quantum physics. In this way, no experimental data is needed for calibrating the CG equations. Thus, in principle, only the Coulomb’s law for the forces on the electrons is needed. If semiphenomenological models are used as the starting point (e.g., ion cores are treated as simple particles), then only the associated parameters (e.g., ion charge, size, etc.) are required. This “data-free” aspect of our multiscale theory is a conceptual triumph, but also is of great practical significance. For example, it avoids the need for extensive experimental data which thereby enables a computer-aided materials design strategy.

Broader Impacts

The multiscale approach delivered via this project may be generalized to address a number of diverse systems. These include ionic liquids, biomacromolecules and supramolecular assemblies such as viruses, as well as nanostructured materials of interest for energy harvesting and storage. It can also be modified to simulate living cells and tissues starting with reaction-transport models. Thus this project has wide potential significance in a range of challenging problems in the pure and applied sciences.

Intellectual Merit

Intuitive arguments on the nature of electronic materials, and notably regarding large-scale disturbances of the many-electron system, are used to initiate a deductive analysis. The analysis starts with the fundamental equation of many particle quantum physics and yields the overall behavior of a nanoscale structure. As a result, the theory avoids the need to conjecture the form of an equation governing large-scale behavior of a many-electron system; rather, all factors in the equations of large-scale quantum dynamics we derive can be readily obtained from the basic laws of quantum physics. This achieves the classic objective of deriving the behavior of complex systems from the fundamental laws of physics. The approach paralleled our earlier work on the theory of many particles evolving via Newton’s equations, and has subsequently inspired the development of methods to solve the Newtonian many-particle problem.
